DOC.HEAD: EC and EFTA Lay Groundwork for European Economic Space
DOC.TEXT: The 19 European Community and seven European Free Trade Association nations agreed Tuesday to begin talks early next year on closer economic cooperation aimed at forging a so-called European Economic Space. The idea is to allow free movement of trade, capital, people and services between the two trade blocs, said officials at a meeting here of the EC and EFTA foreign ministers. The 12 EC nations are to remove their internal borders by late 1992. This project has sparked fears among the seven EFTA nations that the single market will occur at the expense of trade with them. Jon Baldvin Hannibalsson, the foreign minister of Iceland, which currently holds the EFTA presidency, said he was ``immensely satisfied'' with the outcome of Tuesday's meeting. He said the EFTA nations _ Austria, Iceland, Finland, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Liechtenstein _ hoped the talks could start in early 1990 and be concluded by the end of the year. But EC External Relations Commissioner Frans Andriessen was more cautious, saying the talks must end before Dec. 31, 1992, the date by which the EC is to complete its single-market project. The EC's two-way trade with EFTA, $217 billion, is only slightly less than its combined two-way trade with the United States and Japan, which amounts to $230 billion. Andriessen said the ministers singled out problems to be solved in the negotiations for closer economic ties between EFTA and the EC. The most important is the institutional aspect of the new EC-EFTA relationship. He said each side ``should respect the autonomy'' of its own decision-making and that this was ``not negotiable'' for the EC. At best, he said, he could see ``a kind of osmosis'' between the two blocs' decision-making institutions. Hannibalsson said each bloc would continue to monitor compliance with its own laws after the two sides have expanded their economic cooperation, creating what officials term a ``European Economic Space.'' The foreign ministers also agreed to widen cooperation among the 19 nations in such areas as research and development, the environment, education, working conditions and social welfare, consumer protection, programs for small and medium-sized enterprises and tourism. Some cooperation in these areas has already begun. The 1990 European Year of Tourism, for example, is a joint EC-EFTA effort. Separately, the EC and EFTA nations signed an agreement under which they will exchange information on compulsory technical regulations. This accord takes effect July 1, 1990, and is designed to prevent obstacles to trade arising from differences in national technical standards. The ministers also signed an agreement to allow universities and industries in EFTA and EC nations to develop partnerships, exchange students and staff and take part in joint training projects. This agreement comes into force Jan. 1.
